I want to thank the co-leads of our would-be Censure Resolution for their work: Representatives @RepLindaSanchez @RepNikema and @RepLawrence.

I hope that Congress can take the necessary steps to serve as a model to a nation desperately in need of leaders willing to correct themselves when they are wrong, and to engage in a more civil discourse to ultimately work together toward a "more perfect union."
While I will certainly have vehement disagreements with Rep. Greene on policy, politics, and style...
Moving forward, I will continue to call out harmful or dangerous rhetoric by my colleagues, irrespective of which side of the aisle from which it emanates.
In light of her apology, I am electing not to go forward at this time with introducing a resolution of censure.

I was therefore pleasantly surprised to learn that she made the time to visit the Holocaust Memorial Museum (where I have the honor of serving as a trustee), and I appreciate that after her visit she understood the harm of her comparison and offered an apology.
After all, Rep. Greene has a long history of unapologetically inflammatory and dangerous rhetoric.

But when I heard Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene initial make her comparison of our nation’s Covid-response to the Holocaust, and then repeat it again and again, I never expected a retraction or an apology.
Sometimes we may stumble in our message. When we do, we should be given the chance to clarify exactly what we intended to say and promptly set the record straight.

I believe that words matter and that they have consequences. Elected officials, and especially members of Congress, have a great responsibility to carefully measure our words and be as precise as possible when we communicate.

NEW: H.R. 587, the “Ocean Pollution Reduction Act II,” passed the House!

Advanced by T&I in March, H.R. 587 provides the Point Loma Wastewater Treatment Plant in San Diego, California with a path forward to reduce pollution and implement an innovative water recycling program.

NEW: H.R. 2008, the “Local Water Protection Act,” passed the House! 

Introduced by @RepAngieCraig and @RepBrianMast and approved by T&I in March this bipartisan bill will reduce water pollution in local communities by helping states prevent dangerous runoff.

NEW: H.R. 1144, the “Promoting United Government Efforts to Save our Sound Act,” passed the House! 

Introduced by @RepDerekKilmer/@RepStricklandWa, and voted out of T&I in March, the bill supports restoration efforts in the Puget Sound, authorizing $50M/yr. in federal funds.

NEW: H.R. 610, the “San Francisco Bay Restoration Act,” passed the House! 

Introduced by @RepSpeier and advanced by T&I in March, the bill authorizes $25 million annually for restoration activities in the Bay Area.

NEW: H.R. 1703, the “National Children’s Museum Act,” passed the House!

@EleanorNorton’s bill, which cleared our committee in March, directs the @USGSA to enter into a cooperative agreement with the National Children’s Museum for the space the Museum occupies in Washington D.C.

#CryptoLingo: #Cryptocurrency - A subset of virtual currencies that rely on cryptography and distributed ledger technology (DLT) to enable transactions between two parties w/out a third-party facilitator. Ex: #Bitcoin #BTC, #Ether, #Dogecoin. | 📺: https://financialservices.house.gov/calendar/eventsingle.aspx?EventID=407953

#CryptoLingo: Central Bank Digital Currency #CBDC - A subset of virtual currencies that is:
1) issued by a Central Bank of a sovereign state,
2) denominated in a national unit of account,
3) a liability of the issuing Central Bank, & typically
4) has low volatility.

#CryptoLingo: #DigitalCurrency - A subset of digital assets to incl. digital representations of value that are, or aim to be, currency. Typical traits are:
1)widely accepted as a medium of exchange,
2)a reasonable store of value, &
3)a valid metric used to compare items of value.

Shedding some light on crypto, #DidYouKnow that a #DigitalAsset is the most general term to describe anything finance and #crypto adjacent, including cryptocurrencies and central bank digital currencies. Watch our hearing to learn more: https://financialservices.house.gov/calendar/eventsingle.aspx?EventID=407953

We need a new approach to drugs.

Our bill will not only decriminalize personal use and possession of drugs, but it will shift the focus of federal drug policy from the Department of Justice to the Department of Health and Human Services.

From 2001 to 2010 over 7 million people were arrested simply for possession of marijuana. This has contributed to the United States - the land of the free – with the highest incarceration rate in the world. And none of this has made a dent in our use of drugs.

Our approach until now has not been to help sick people with treatment and counseling, but to throw them in jail. Along the way, we’ve seen millions get swept up in a criminal justice system that completely derails their lives and those of their families.

https://watsoncoleman.house.gov/newsroom/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=1834
@SessiBlanchard @CoriBush Our bill charges HHS with establishing a “Commission on Substance Use, Health and Safety,” to determine the benchmark amounts for drug possession with a focus on health.

RT @tomangell @RepBonnie @RepCori The new Drug Policy Reform Act would shift responsibility for drug classification from DOJ to HHS—treating drugs like a health issue.

It would also end collateral consequences in housing, food assistance, employment, immigration status and other areas for drug possession.

We need a new approach; one that recognizes that we need not lock people away. 

Those that are struggling with drugs should be handled by doctors and counselors, not judges and jailers.
